S7.T1.caption:
Table 1: Results and comparisons on real-world datasets in the form of mean accuracy Â±plus-or-minus\pm standard deviation and are obtained over 3 repetitions in different random seeds.
Results are averaged over the last 505050 rounds.
The total number of global rounds is 2000
for SVHN, CIFAR-10 and CINIC-10.
Algorithms are categorized into two groups:
(1) ones not aided by memory or known statistics;
(2) ones assisted by memory.
For a fair competition,
we boldface the best accuracy in the first group,
while the second best is underlined.

references:
Non-stationary client unavailability.
A total of four unavailable dynamics are evaluated inÂ TableÂ 1,
including
stationary and
non-stationary with
staircase,
sine and
interleaved sine trajectories,
with their visualizations available in the same table.
The classification tasks become more challenging as the list progresses
due to the growing complexity in the non-stationary dynamics.
Furthermore,
our choices of the non-stationary dynamics are motivated by real-world federated learning participation statistics,
for example, sine trajectory [3],
and by generalizing the existing participation patterns
such as cyclic participation [8, 53].
In particular,
the interleaved sine dynamics is
more challenging than
the vanilla cyclic availability dynamics
since clients become available during each active period with probability that is less than 111 and non-stationary simultaneously.
Formally,
client iğ‘–iâ€™s dynamics is defined as pit=piâ‹…fiâ€‹(t)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘¡â‹…subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¡p_{i}^{t}=p_{i}\cdot f_{i}(t),
where fiâ€‹(t)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¡f_{i}(t) is a time-dependent function under non-stationary dynamics
but fiâ€‹(t)=1subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¡1f_{i}(t)=1 when stationary,
and pi=âŸ¨Î½i,Ï•âŸ©subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğœˆğ‘–italic-Ï•p_{i}=\left\langle\nu_{i},\phi\right\rangle.
Ï•italic-Ï•\phi characterizes the unbalanced contribution of different image classes to the generated probabilities.
Each element of [Ï•]csubscriptdelimited-[]italic-Ï•ğ‘[\phi]_{c} is drawn from ğ–´ğ—‡ğ—‚ğ–¿ğ—ˆğ—‹ğ—†â€‹(0,ğš½c)ğ–´ğ—‡ğ—‚ğ–¿ğ—ˆğ—‹ğ—†0subscriptğš½ğ‘\mathsf{Uniform}(0,\bm{\Phi}_{c}),
where a smaller ğš½csubscriptğš½ğ‘\bm{\Phi}_{c} leads to a less significant contribution of that image class.
It is immediately clear that
the coupling of local data distribution (Î½iâˆ¼ğ–£ğ—‚ğ—‹ğ—‚ğ–¼ğ—ğ—…ğ–¾ğ—â€‹(Î±=0.1))similar-tosubscriptğœˆğ‘–ğ–£ğ—‚ğ—‹ğ—‚ğ–¼ğ—ğ—…ğ–¾ğ—ğ›¼0.1(\nu_{i}\sim\mathsf{Dirichlet(\alpha=0.1)}) and class contribution Ï•italic-Ï•\phi leads to non-independent pisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–p_{i}â€™s.
In addition,
AssumptionÂ 1 will not hold in the case of interleaved sine non-stationary dynamics
since pitsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘¡p_{i}^{t}â€™s occasionally reach 0.
Although
being agnostic to
the challenging client unavailability dynamics not covered by our analysis,
we observe thatÂ FedAWEÂ retains its outperformance.
Comparisons will be specified next.

Training curves.
In this part,
we show the training curves ofÂ FedAvgÂ over active clients,Â FedAWEÂ andÂ MIFA.
In particular,
the presented results ofÂ FedAWEÂ are after
exponential moving average
[5] under a parameter 0.990.990.99.
Note that this is to ease down the noisy progress,
and for a neat presentation only,
the reported results in the main text and ablation studies are all from raw data.
Fig.Â 7(a) plots the train loss and test accuracy from raw data.
For example,
when compared withÂ Fig.Â 7(b),
EMA eases down the fluctuations but does not change either the trend or the order of algorithm performance results.
All train losses are plotted on a logarithmic scale.
The results are consistent withÂ TableÂ 1.

Impact of system-design parameters.
In this part,
we study the impact of system-design parameter
including
the degree of non-stationarity Î³ğ›¾\gamma
and data heterogeneity Î±ğ›¼\alpha
under non-stationary with sine trajectory.
The results are inÂ TableÂ 9 andÂ TableÂ 10.
Overall,Â FedAWEÂ keeps outperforming the algorithms not assisted by memories or known statistics.

InÂ TableÂ 10,
clientsâ€™ local data becomes more heterogeneous when Î±ğ›¼\alpha increases.
We can see a clear increase trend in accuracy.
However,
FedAWEÂ remains to attain the best accuracies both train and test when compared to the algorithms not aided by memory or known statistics.
Moreover,
it outperformsÂ MIFA,
which consumes a lot of storage space,
when Î±=0.1ğ›¼0.1\alpha=0.1 and 1.01.01.0.
The observations confirm the practicality ofÂ FedAWE.

When the local data sets are homogeneous,
âˆ‡Fiâ€‹(ğ’™)=âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ’™)âˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğ’™âˆ‡ğ¹ğ’™\nabla F_{i}({\bm{x}})=\nabla F({\bm{x}}) holds for any client iâˆˆ[m]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘ši\in[m],
resulting in Î²=Î¶=0ğ›½ğœ0\beta=\zeta=0.
AssumptionÂ 4 and its variants (seeÂ TableÂ 2 inÂ AppendixÂ C) are often referred to as bounded gradient dissimilarity assumption to account for data heterogeneity across clients.
It can be easily checked that ourÂ AssumptionÂ 4 is more relaxed or equivalent to the variants therein.

A11.T8.caption:
Table 8: The first round to reach a targeted test accuracy under
non-stationary of sine trajectory
over 3 random seeds.
We study the first round to reach 1/4141/4, 1/2121/2, 3/4343/4 and 111 of the best test accuracy of each dataset in TableÂ 1,
which is rounded up to the nearest 10%percent1010\% below for ease of presentation.
In addition,
we sample the mean of test accuracy every 20 global rounds to mitigate noisy progress.
Some algorithms may never attain the targeted accuracy
due to their inferior performance,
where we use â€œâ€“â€ as a placeholder.

Implicit gossiping.
InÂ FedAWE, the parameter server does not send the most recent global model to the active clients at the beginning of a round. Instead, the parameter server aggregates the locally updated models ğ’™itâ£â€ superscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘–ğ‘¡â€ {\bm{x}}_{i}^{t\dagger} and sends the new global model ğ’™t+1superscriptğ’™ğ‘¡1{\bm{x}}^{t+1} to all active clients ğ’œtsuperscriptğ’œğ‘¡{\mathcal{A}}^{t} (lines 14-15).
By postponing multicasting the shared global model,
the active clients in ğ’œtsuperscriptğ’œğ‘¡{\mathcal{A}}^{t} implicitly gossip
their updated local models with each other through the parameter server [56].
Though the postponed multi-cast brings in staleness, simple coupling argument show that the staleness is bounded (LemmaÂ 2).
In addition,
our empirical results (TableÂ 8 inÂ AppendixÂ K) suggest that there is no significant slowdown when compared to vanillaÂ FedAvg.
Gossip-type algorithms were originally proposed for peer-to-peer networks and are well-known for their agility to communication failures and asynchronous information exchange in achieving average consensus
[12, 4, 22, 15, 29, 34].
Intuitively, the clientsâ€™ local estimates are eventually equally weighted in the
final algorithm output.
Note that,
departing from
the standard gossiping protocols therein [22, 44],
information exchange inÂ FedAWEÂ does not involve client-client communication.
The information mixing matrix underÂ FedAWEÂ is defined inÂ (3), which is doubly stochastic.
We characterize the information mixing error,
i.e., consensus error inÂ LemmaÂ 1.

Benchmark algorithms and discussions.
We compareÂ FedAWEÂ with six baseline algorithms,
including
FedAvgÂ over active clients [30],
FedAvgÂ over all clients, FedAUÂ [53],
F3ASTÂ [42],
FedAvgÂ with known pitsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘¡p_{i}^{t}â€™Â [40],
andÂ MIFAÂ [13].
The details of the algorithm and the additional results
are deferred toÂ AppendixÂ K.
It is observed thatÂ FedAWEÂ consistently outperforms the algorithms not aided by memory.
Surprisingly,
FedAWEÂ occasionally beatsÂ MIFA,
which is memory heavy.
We attribute it to reuse of stored gradients from the unavailable clients.
AlthoughÂ FedAWEÂ brings in stalenss due to implicit gossiping,
our results (TableÂ 8 inÂ AppendixÂ K) indicate that there is no significant slowdown forÂ FedAWEÂ when compared to vanillaÂ FedAvg,
where we study the first round to achieve a targeted accuracy by different algorithms.
In addition,
FedAWEÂ attains competitive or even better performance thanÂ FedAvgÂ with known probability,
yet unknown to the underlying dynamics in client unavailability.

Staleness studies.
TableÂ 8
illustrates the first round to reach a targeted test accuracy under non-stationary client availability with sine trajectory.
Specifications can be found in the caption.
It can be easily checked that,
during the initial stage (the first three quarters),
FedAWEÂ slightly lags behindÂ FedAvgÂ over active
clients.
However,
when reaching the final stage (the last quarter),
FedAWEÂ attains the target accuracy in a comparable or lower number of rounds toÂ FedAvgÂ over active clients in the evaluations on SVHN and CINIC-10 datasets.
The slowdown ofÂ FedAWEÂ on CIFAR-10 dataset is worth further investigation.
In general, we arrive numerically at the conclusion that
the staleness incurred by implicit gossiping inÂ FedAWEÂ is mild.

Impact of system-design parameters.
In this part,
we study the impact of system-design parameter
including
the degree of non-stationarity Î³ğ›¾\gamma
and data heterogeneity Î±ğ›¼\alpha
under non-stationary with sine trajectory.
The results are inÂ TableÂ 9 andÂ TableÂ 10.
Overall,Â FedAWEÂ keeps outperforming the algorithms not assisted by memories or known statistics.

InÂ TableÂ 10,
clientsâ€™ local data becomes more heterogeneous when Î±ğ›¼\alpha increases.
We can see a clear increase trend in accuracy.
However,
FedAWEÂ remains to attain the best accuracies both train and test when compared to the algorithms not aided by memory or known statistics.
Moreover,
it outperformsÂ MIFA,
which consumes a lot of storage space,
when Î±=0.1ğ›¼0.1\alpha=0.1 and 1.01.01.0.
The observations confirm the practicality ofÂ FedAWE.
